Replace three way valve in titan reset relief valve # 4 control cabinet Replace three way valve in titan reset relief valve control cabinet During drilling ops the mud pump #4 reset relief valve got opened, Bob checked found the rig air pressure went down for a while also checked the cabinet for any abnormalities. There is a air leak on the three way valve through the vent. Normal expected wear and tear from operating equipment as designed  As Per request from maint sup part request canceled and job closed as the unit was repaired during the troubleshooting.----------, Parts Requested from ICS:----------, ** Non Issued Parts Auto Cancelled QTY REQUESTED: 2 QTY ISSUED: 0 DESC: VALVE SOLENOID 24 VDC 3WAY 316SS CE Z1----------, Part Number: P991000423 was cancelled from the job.'

Replace defective mud pump blower motor #1A deteriorated due to heavy vibration. Replace defective mud pump blower motor #1A which is deteriorated due to heavy vibration. Failure related to operation/use or maintenance of the equipment but no further details known  This job is being made for replacing the mud pump #1A blower motor which deteriorating due to heavy vibration.The bolts on the terminal cover had broken twice and the impeller is very rough.There is an old motor and impellor assembly lying in thruster space which was removed due to vibration. The plan is to assemble a blower assembly using spare motor lying in ballast pump room which was order on job number115720.This is a replacement motor offered by Siemens and more details can be found in that job.We also have new impellors on board and this also will be used for assembling it.The motor has been requested on this job.----------, new impller has been recevied ICN # 10023935 from the store and new motor dessembiled the old motor and old imppler from the old frame was in thruster #3 to use the foam sealed between the motor and frame mounting flange and during the assemilation the of the old frame mounting flange has been found cracked all the way from the eadge to the center get an empty frame from thruster #3 and assembild the motor on the frame and installed the imppler to the motor shaft adjusted the impller gap between the imppler and mounting flange to 140 mm (keep in mind the rubber sealed and imppler housing thkness ) as the impller 180 mm and impller housing 200 mm adjusted the imppler in center of the mounting flange secuered and the imppler bolts and tighten all the bolts rigged up all the liftting gears above the mud pump #1 as the plane is only remove the motor frame with the imppler attched to the motor scuerd the the whole frame and motor then undo all the mounting flange bolts and removed the whole motor and motor frame and impller by slided out from the imppler housing then trnasfreed down get the new assemaly readt at the mud pump room and lifted up and slided inside the impller housing secuerd all the bolts and removed all liftting gears the handover to day crew to be connected up and inspect the cleanes between the imppler from the other side of the impller housing .----------, The junction box of the mud pump was repositioned and the power was connected.Function tested it and rattling noise started due to the loose louvers.This was rectified with rubber packings around.There was still abit ofrattlig sound which was from the side plate where lever is connected to rotate the mud pump manually.This was also fixed and now the noise was gone. The vibration level was a bit more than the other one probably because the unit isn't balanced but there is no other spare onboard to fix it as of now.The RLA was 15amps.Test run it for 5 hrs and then put it back in service.Job has now been completed.Plan is to make one assembly of defective motor prepare a complete assembly from what is remaining and send it ot Lifiting for overhaul and balancing.----------, Parts Requested from ICS:

Suspend drilling operations due to issues with Hex pumps 1, 2 and 3 requiring repair to fluid ends. Hex pump #1 - Leaking liner gasket that is currently being repaired. Failed Module on Hex pump #1 Bay #2 Hex pump #2 - Washed module in #2 Bay. We have one more module in the warehouse to replace this with. We also have had to steal 2 sub rods for the pistons out of this pump to replace one each in pump #1 and #3. We are out of sub rods so this pump will definitely be down until 2 sub rods are received. There are 2 sub rods in the weekly shipment at the dock. Hex pump # 3 is down due to the washed module that was replaced yesterday. New module is installed and going back together with the S pipe. Hope to have it up within the hour. Hex Pump #4 Bay 2 has a valve and seat outside of Suction seat is busted and washed. Unknown at this time, NOV and TFS is still investigating. Unknown at this time. Pick up off bottom and circulate with pumps 4 and 5 until other pumps available. We have submitted a large rig down order of spare parts, CVX has committed to running a special boat for us. TCO ticket 994750 has been opened with NOV and e hawk has been trending the pumps to see is there is a synchronization issue.

TROUBLESHOOT ABNORMAL TORQUE AND POWER READINGS Breakdown Job Normal expected wear and tear from operating equipment as designed  MUD PUMP RAN FOLLOWING THE REPLACEMENT OF THE PORT SIDE BELT 3A RPM 509 Mact 800 I act 400 V out 347 P out 40 3B RPM 512 Mact Neg 190 I act 395 V out 348 P out Neg 10 MUD PUMP RAN FOLLOWING THE REPLACEMENT OF THE PORT SIDE BELT AND WITH LOAD 3A RPM 393 Mact 3420 I act 512 V out 273 P out 140 3B RPM 394 Mact 2660 I act 475 V out 273 P out 115----------, MEASURED MOTOR CURRENT VALUES AND COMPARED WITH VFD CURRENT READINGS. MP 3A VFD Iact = 392 Motor Phase Measurement 392 Per Phase MP 3B VFD IAct = 396 Motor Phase Readings 396 Per Phase----------, 24/4/18 CNR PUNCHLIST ITEM 304 POWER IMBALANCE BETWEEN A ND B MOTOR We assigned all mud pumps in a controlled manner in order to easily check the Bender feedback. MP1 140k MP3 135K MP4 115K MP5 115K We then ran MP3 up to 80rpm in order to observe the reported difference in torque and power feedback. See link to video which clearly show a large difference in torque and power values basically the values on B motor are always reading negative. I:\Electrical\#3 Mud Pump\Mud Pump 3\20180424_071329.mp4 Note no alarms were activated during the test. Following this we test ran each motor individually and observed the following readings. Motor 3A RPM 206 Mact 400 Nm Iact 380a Vout 140v Pact 10Kw Motor 3B RPM 207 Mact 400 Nm Iact 380a Vout 140v Pact 10Kw Following the discovery of an old email (see attached) which mentions issues with both MP 3 and 5 dating from back in 2011 we ran MP and the following readings were observed. As you can see MP 5 shows similar differences. MP5A. RPM 822.1 Mact 300 Nm Iact 400a Vout 561v Pact 30Kw Motor 5B RPM 820.8 Mact 700 Nm Iact 400a Vout 561v Pact 60Kw For good measure we also checked MP1 and MP4. As you can see MP1 looks fairly balanced however MP4 shows similar differences in Torque and Power. Motor 1A RPM 820 Mact 500 Nm Iact 400a Vout 560v Pact 45Kw Motor 1B RPM 820 Mact 500 Nm Iact 400a Vout 560v Pact 45Kw MP4A. RPM 821 Mact 700 Nm Iact 400a Vout 560v Pact 61Kw Motor 4B RPM 822 Mact 400 Nm Iact 400a Vout 560v Pact 32Kw----------, MUD PUMP 3 RAN WITH LOAD. 3A RPM 810 Mact 3660 I act 515 V out 559 P out 321 3B RPM 820 Mact 2050 I act 450 V out 562 P out 178----------, Folloing the discovery of emails dating back from 2009/20011 which indicated that incorrect belt and pulley allignmnet was the probable cause of the issue it was decided to check mud pump 3. Motor isolated for mechanical checks THE FOLLOWING READINGS WERE TAKEN FOLLOWING THE FIRST MECHANICAL ADJUSTMENT Motor 3A RPM 815 Mact 1510 Nm Iact 416a Vout 558v Pact 128Kw Motor 3B RPM 824 Mact Neg 530 Nm Iact 404a Vout 561v Pact Neg 47Kw----------, FOLLOWING THE FINAL TEST MAINT SUP WAS ABLE TO CLOSE OUT THE ISSUE WITH CLIENT.----------, Checked belt alignment; 3a found slightly off one turn of the adjustment screw made the alignment of motor visually perfect using a wire clamped from one sheave to the other. Belt tension checked at 85 psi. 3b aligned earlier.----------, THE FOLLOWING READINGS WERE TAKEN FOLLOWING THE 2ND MECHANICAL ADJUSTMENT OF MP3. Motor 3A RPM 815 Mact 1500 Nm Iact 420a Vout 558v Pact 130Kw Motor 3B RPM 823 Mact Neg 500 Nm Iact 405a Vout 560v Pact Neg 45Kw----------, THE FOLLOWING READINGS WERE TAKEN FOLLOWING THE 1ST MECHANICAL ADJUSTMENT OF MP4. Motor 4A RPM 815 Mact 1500 Nm Iact 420a Vout 558v Pact 130Kw Motor 4B RPM 823 Mact Neg 500 Nm Iact 405a Vout 560v Pact Neg 45Kw

Troublesoot and fix the issue of noisy DE bearing on mud pump#1A drive motor. Troublesoot and take necessary corrective action to fix the issue of noisy DE bearing on mud pump#1A drive motor Equipment did not perform as intended per designed specification and not due to lack of maintenance  ID RUN was successfully completed (refer to attached procedure). A backup of the original Parameters and new Paramters (after ID RUN) were uploaded. Software Library will be updated. NOTE 1: As per the Drive Manual prior to performing the ID Run the motor parameters need to be updated to reflect the data on the nameplate of the motor. Despite the fact the motor was changed out with the same type/model some motor characteristics are slightly different (i.e. motor current nominal speed frequency KW). As per feedback from ABB the original motor data needs to be maintained in the drive parameters. These parameters have been optimized for the running of the mudpumps. Since the mudpumps are also part of a 2 motor setup this parameters should be identical to ensure correct load sharing between the motors. NOTE 2: As per feedback from ABB also the following needs to be done prior to following ABB's procedure on performing a Mud Pump Motor ID RUN: Remove CH0 fiber from the RDCO board to ensure external control system is unable to overwrite any parameters during the ID RUN process. Verify Parameter 20.17 P MOT LIMIT is set to 100%. If not change this value to 100%. Please note that this value will be automatically overwritten when CH0 is reconnected at the RDCO board. You can also manually change this Parameter back to original value before reconnecting CH0.----------, Reconnected Mud Pump 1A Blower supply cable. Deisolated Blower and rotation checked and working properly and no abnormal noise.----------, Continue work on Mud Pump #1A mounted back the Motor Junction Box using chain block line up Terminal box to the motor and installed all bolts space heater connected all motor cables closed all covers drilled holes on Space heater terminal box and Winding RTD's terminal box reconnected all wirings. Ongoing job for Motor ID Run.----------, The mechanics had informed about abnormal noise from the mud pump #1 A end .Initially it looked like some vibrating frame but then figured out it is the noise from the drive end of the bearing of motor #1 A. Confirmed this by using stethoscope and temperature gun. Knocking sound was present at the drive end and temperature of the drive end was around 62 degrees Celsius the NDE the temperatures were OK around 38 degrees. Checked the DE & NDE temperatures of motor #1B #2A & #2B.All the DE temperatures were around 48 degrees and NDE was around 38.Pumped in Cyprinia RA grease around 100 shots on DE of motor #1A and noise subsided .At this point the abnormal noise from the bearing can only be heard with a stethoscope. Still there was a knocking noise from the DE bearing of motor#1A .Decided to monitor the noise and temperature every hour but after a while the operation required shutting down the pumps. Seelan had opened up the inspection cover and checked it for any abnormalities .None found and felt the need of more grease .He also pumped grease in it and left it operation just to monitor the temperatures and vibration .The pump doesn't have any load now .The speed was increased and it has been left running and temperature is being monitored .The temperature at the DE is now 58 degrees and NDE is 35 degrees .On motor #1B DE is 45 degrees and NDE IS 35 degrees.----------, Megger New Motor for MP 1A replacement. IR @ 1000 V/ 60 secs : 2.56 Gohms----------, Motor Nameplate details: New MP1A Motor: Model:CM628TUT120BL S/N: SE60CM97331 Old MP1A Motor: Model: CM628TUT120BL S/N: WC60CM43941----------, Worked on Mud Pump #1 Motor 1A replacement disconnected Blower 1A motor supply cable Main motor space heater cables pressure switch and rtd's. Disconnected Main Motor 1A motor cables in the terminal box and remove all terminal box mounting bolts and used chain block to remove the complete terminal box. Removed all tools. Ongoing jobs Drilling Department and Mechanical Department to remove the Blower Motor 1A and Main Motor 1A.----------, As per the below the mud piump motor has been replaced in light of this I am closing this job out----------, The temperatures of the DE bearing for MP1A was monitored and it has been alwas around 68 degrees.The new motor assembly which was there in the thruster#3 space has now been shifted to the mud pump room.This motor model has the initial ending with BL which was confirmed prior to shifting.The motor was meggered and it is fine.We had a quick look at the tools needed for the job these were some that were required for dismantling it. 1. Spaners/ socket set: 14mm.17 mm.19mm 10mm & 24mm. 2.Chain blocks1 ton & 5 ton. 3.Adjustable for glands and some fittings.Thexact size of the motor mounting bolts arent checked and for this mecahnics or drill crew can help when required.----------, The pump #1 has been running since 8 hrs at full load and the temperature of the DE end was monitored every 2 hrs and it was 64 degrees.This pump was started because drill crew had to clean the stariner of pump#4.When the pump #4 is ready to use this pump will be changed over.NDE is 45 degrees----------, The mud pump was running a few days ago for a long time and the maximum temperature that DE bearing had reached was 72 degrees.This was informed to the toolpusher & electrical supervisor as the other pumps were idle and pump #3 was pumping very slow.At the next available oppurtunity this pump was shut down and changed over.NDE bearings were 45 degrees.

Rebuild manual bleed off valve Rebuild manual bleed off valve Normal expected wear and tear from operating equipment as designed  Parts received----------, ** Non Issued Parts Auto Cancelled QTY REQUESTED: 2 QTY ISSUED: 0 DESC: disc rupture specified 5172 psi at 72 f QTY REQUESTED: 2 QTY ISSUED: 0 DESC: wrench rupture disk plug for 31/16 in----------, Parts Requested from ICS:

While circulating and conditioning mud while the client was making decisions on hole direction, We had swabs starting to leak on mud pump #2 (cylinder #2), then mud pump #3 (cylinder 1-3), mud pump #1 (cylinder 1) and mud pump #4 (cylinders 1-3). Under investigation due to swabs having less than 30 hours on them. Continue to monitor liner wash to determine worn swabs ahead of time NOTE: changed to correct swab type for Oil based mud use. (Patriot) Replaced swabs that were available (3 new swabs available and 8 used swabs available). 4 hours of the time acquired due to waiting on 4 mud pumps to be available. Client has requested mud pump #5 be isolated and used for completions only. We had 3 pumps operational (#1 - #3). The time was to pull swabs on mud pump #4, clean pump & liner wash tank, and replace swabs on mud pump #4 (that we had to wait to get off a crew boat).

No.1 mud pump PRV, Order replacement TITAN P.R.V. Order replacement TITAN P.R.V. to replace one that was damaged beyond economic repair Inadequate equipment design or configuration (shape, size, technology, configuration, operability, maintainability, etc.), but no further details known  RMS job 2220014162682 has been created for the valve which was removed from Mud Pump # 3 Plans are to overhaul the unit & install on Mud pump # 1----------, Equipment is out of Service Equipment is back in Service Tagged as OOS. This valve did not fail. It was tagged as failed on #1.----------, We finally received the first of two new BX Titan valves onboard. This valve has been modified it has the vent holes drilled just below Bonnet assy. as per HQSOPSTIBPRV009. The numbers or data on this new valve is as follows: NOV Titan BX serial number 23423363 Valve # 10111643001. As stated below though this valve was ordered for pump no. 1 we installed it on pump no. 3. The BX Titan that was on the no. 3 pump has not been modified or had the vent holes drilled in the bonnet. While we do have a safety clamp for this particular valve it could not be placed on this no. 3 mud pump because of structural clearance between the valve and high pressure pipe work. We have placed the new valve at this location will rebuild or reseal the valve that was removed and place it on a different pump and use the safety clamp.----------, Valve has been tested on the Mud Side by drilling dept. No leaks found. Valve in full service now.----------, Equipment is back in Service Tagged as OOS. This valve did not fail. It was tagged as failed on #1.----------, ** This Titan Valve has been installed on #3 Mud Pump as per instructions from Mech Sup**. 1. Removed original BX Titan valve from pipe work. 2. Cleaned up pipe connections and installed new seals. 3. Installed new modified BX Titan valve into place. 4. Removed pressure transducer from pipe work and connected to hydraulic test tool. 5. Tested pressure transduder to 500psi 1500psi 3000psi & 6500psi. Valve open at each set point with no issues. This was witnessed & verified by Rufat Toolpusher. 6. Awaiting drilling dept to test the mud side of the BX Titan before signing off the job as completed.----------, Equipment is out of Service Tagged as OOS. This valve did not fail. It was tagged as failed on #1.----------, Equipment is back in Service Equipment is back in Service Tagged as OOS. This valve did not fail. It was tagged as failed on #1.----------, Parts Requested from ICS:---------- , AUTOMATED PRIORITY ADJUSTMENT Job priority changed from Medium(4) to 1 due to revised job priority methodology.

Need to change seals in mud pump 3 rod 2. Need to change seals in mud pump 3 rod 2. Failure caused by wear and tear resulting from normal operation of the equipment unit  Parts Requested from ICS:----------Mark E , new seals installed. new oring installed as well torqued and tie wired bolts installed cover----------Mark E , Parts Requested from ICS:----------, Deisolated and test ran with derrick hand. Ran pump at over 130 strokes per minute.

During drilling operations burst disc failed on mud pump 1. Current operations involve downlinking to rotary steerable tools using a bypass downlink system. Previous operations have shown this method to weaken the burst discs leading to premature failure. Plan to install different design of unloaders when equipment becomes available to the rig. Isolated mud pump and replaced disc.

filter oil off-line to remove water and contamination as per oil sample reports allow the water to settle out to the bottom of the sump and use a pump and suction wand to remove a 20 liters of oil from the bottom of thew sump. filter the oil off-line to remove water and contamination, remove oil trough end covers to drain collected water, Failure caused by wear and tear resulting from normal operation of the equipment unit  1. The portable filtration unit was used however as its designed for hydraulic oil it kept tripping the motor. 2. We found the source of the water ingress to be coming from the stroke counter wires which run through a gland located on top of the crosshead chamber. (See RMS Job# 171767). 3. New wiper seals have been requested on RMS Job# 171816.

Replace MP3 pulsation dampener diaphram Replace MP3 pulsation dampener diaphram Topp off nitrogen to 2000psi Several causes are acting simultaneously. If one cause is predominant, this cause should be highlighted.  Parts Requested from ICS:----------, Mud Pump 3: Remove the Air operated hoist on the trolley and install a manual hoist for the task. Gather all tools and equipment as needed. Create a new RRP and WRA for replacing the bladder. Isolated the mud pump and the fluid end valves. Removed the fill valve and gauge. Removed the top cover and found that the hex bolt that secures the stabilizer to the diaphragm had back out. The stabilizer was found to be split and in poor condition. Rigged up lifting eye and removed the diaphragm. Clean the flange and cavity and fit the new diaphragm. Reinstall the cover fill valve and gauges. Rig up and fill with 2000psi nitrogen pre charge.

While drilling the derrick hand discovered and unusual smell in the pump room. Investigation uncovered that oil was observed through transparent cover. The mud pump was stopped for repair. Leaking seal between chain case and motor. - Keep spare motor on board. - Level II investigation initiated to: a) Establish cause of motor seal failure. b) Why no spare motor or hub puller on board. c) What could have been done differently to reduce NPT. The motor was opened and the oil was cleaned out from the motor. The commutator was dressed and new brushes was installed. The insulation in the motor was measured and found ok. Filters in the cooling box was renewed. Attempts to loosen Hub from tapered shaft failed, as tools/fittings rated for required pressure not found. Applied 700bar, procedure recommend 1500 bar. While this was ongoing, the boat with new motor arrived. Decision then made to renew the motor instead of change the seal on contaminated motor.

Observed leak on piston number #1 on MP #2. Also observed noise from piston #2. Worn piston / washout. Evaluate to change piston on a more frequent hrs. Decided to replace both pistons. Isolated MP and changed piston on cylinder 1 & 2 on MP #2

Whilst displacing the well from sea water to 1.60sg oil base mud, a sudden loss in stand pipe pressure was observed (max circulation pressure at the time was 1750psi) Driller immediately shut down all mud pumps. The Derrickman confirmed that the discharge dampener on Mud pump #3 had broke off it's mounting and was wedged in the ducting/pipework above the pump. Note: No personnel were in the pump-room area at the time. Equipment Failure - Further details to follow once investigations are carried out. Investigation ongoing. Recovery plan in place. Cleaning mud pump room, removing OBM. Ongoing with securing pulsation dampener, investigating failure and replacement pulsation assemblies mobilised.

Lost 20 bar pump pressure after pumping a high visc pill. A plastc pice was caught between the seat and valve on suction side on cyl #3. Inspected all suction filters on supercharge pumps. Latest action : All 3 strainers for supercharge pumps are modified. Extended top of filters by 2 cm to minimize the opening between the top cover and filter. Opened and inspected all cylinders on MP #2. Removed a plastic pice from suction valve on cyl #3.

Change out faulty L.O pump pressure gauge Change out faulty L.O Pump Pressure Gauge Equipment did not perform as intended per designed specification and not due to lack of maintenance  Parts Requested from ICS:----------, Found mud pump no# 3 lube oil leak from pressure gauge same changed with new one.

Clean suctions strainers prior to drilling 9-7/8" x 11" hole section. When the pumps were bought online #2 mud pump #2 suction cap leaked. Pumps were stop and mud pumps reconfigured. Upon investigation it was found that the cap gasket was left out during reassembling. Coaching and better oversight and verification by Derrickman to confrm.. Pump was re-isolated and gasket was installed.

OOS 2018 Dietswell Punchlist Item No14 OOS 2018 Integrated Punchlist Item 14 Repair or Replace the leaking Lube Oil Pump on No4 Mud Pump Normal expected wear and tear from operating equipment as designed  Parts Requested from ICS:----------, Parts Requested from ICS:----------, When testing the L.O. Pump the Discharge Pressure Gauge was found to be faulty so changed same and tested all O/K.----------, ** Non Issued Parts Auto Cancelled QTY REQUESTED: 2 QTY ISSUED: 0 DESC: PUMP ROTARY GEAR FOOT MOUNT NO.2 WITH R----------, Repairs carried out by Alen Lopes & Joytesh Shah. ' 1. Isolated Mud Pump & verified isolation. 2. Removed L.O Pump coupling guard and pump from skid. 3. Cleaned up all pipework and pump base. 4. Installed new pump and pipework. 5. The 12 hrs recorded under Andrew Christie are for Alen & Joytesh's time as they do not have RMS log in details. 6. Pump can not be function tested as the electrical motor failed the inspection and requires to be changed out. (Electrical Dept aware and plan to change out A.S.A.P).----------, 1. Job has been completed and tested.

Mudpump #1 - Pulsation dampener pressure high pumpman reported pressure on pulsation dampener is high i.e, 3400 psi instead of 1500 psi preset. troubleshoot / investigate. Normal expected wear and tear from operating equipment as designed  Job carried out with RMS# 2230014175563----------, Pumpman Reported Mud pump #1 pulsation dampener pressure shows 3400 psi. Ensured discharge is bleed off and checked the pressure from the filling valve and shows the same 3400 psi.

Charge pump for Mud pump # 4- Mechanical seal leacking, Charge pump for Mud pump # 4- Mechanical seal leacking Normal expected wear and tear from operating equipment as designed  Isolation carried out started dismantling Dismantle pump and cleaned all bolts parts etc.. Replaced stuffing box/wear plate with new due to worn condition Replaced wear sleeve and installed new mechanical seal Impeller in good condition and installed same one back Adjusted gap between impeller and stuffing box to 0.020 as recommended Assembled complete pump and installed back suction and discharge flexible joint Replaced 6 discharge flex joint due to bad condition De isolated fluid end of pump and el.motor Packings will be installed after testing Pump cannot be test operated at this moment due to current drilling operations----------, Charge pump for Mud pump # 4 Mechanical seal leacking Folowing parts required Mechanikal seal ICN 10004061 D09/2 each/$222 Sleeve ICN 10000698D09/ 2 each/$178 Gasket ICN 10004091D09A/1 each/

Replace rupture disk on MP#4 Change disk on MP#4 WOM valve. The equipment was operated beyond capacity of the Equipment Technical Specifications.  Parts Requested from ICS:----------, Installed new disk on MP4.

Electronic relief valve on mud pump no 3 was activated during a connection. There was no indication that to high pressure was the cause. Not able to reset the relief valve. Damage pressure transmiter caused the BX Titan valve to open. When this condition happens the BX Titan valve is programmed to go into fail safe mode and fail safe is open valve; fail safe open. Failed Pressure transmitter is send onshore to NOV/Vendor for analyses. MSN nr 1032000054 and NOV ticket 808994. Review maintenance history in RMS for POP OFF on mud pump 1-2-3 from installation in 2016 and until now and see if the maintenance is correct or if modification is needed. Lesson Learned AAR is to be informed to Drill Crew and Technical Crew so if this fault happened again we are reducing the off line time for this equipment Attempting to reset pop off several times. The alarms "Discharge pressure signal fault" and "Titan BX valve tripped" could be read on the contoller box. Trouble shooting in both the BX Controller box/cabinet and the pressure transmitter to try to pin point the problem. At the same time the mechanich was looking into solutions to use the air from the manifold box controlling the pop off nr 2, to keep the pop off open with that signal. Electrician was able to measeure the signal from the pressure transmitter and found out this was not working. Replaced pressure transmiter on MP #3 and the pop off valve closed.

Piston rubbers on cylinder #1 and #2 washed out: While drilling the liner wash for cylinder #1 and #2 on Mud pump #2 plugged up, causing piston rubbers on Cyl"1 and #2 to wash out. The temperature of the mud in the pits was at that time 55 deg. Celsius. Piston Failure/wash-out - 0.5 hr Downtime for repair BECAUSE Inadequate cooling / Liner spray plugged BECAUSE Inadequate Cleaning of cooling system AND Not observed when plugging The plugging was not discovered in time to prevent washing out the pistons. TD of well is now reached. Liner spray pan and system completely cleaned out while running casing liner. All 3 mud pumps cleaned out and checked one by one. RMS job # 1710036165751 created for history and reliability tracking. Change request PM job created to improve quality of Periodic manintenace, tracking nr. 1710036002480. Lessons learned and Experience transfer communicated to all crews (Synergi 11908). Replaced Pistons, and opened plugged liner wash. Cleaned out the liner wash system, and found some debris in the system which can plug the spray.

Mud pump motor B failed on mud pump 4 whilst drilling 17-1/2" hole. Mud pump was shut down and operations resumed with remaining 3 mud pumps. This event was the direct cause of improper lubrication to the mud pump motor. This can also be attributed to not following PM procedures, not following PMSR procedures, and also having inadequate reactivation procedures. Other mud pumps bearings evaluated with temperature gun and thermal imaging to verify no hot spots were present. Crews made aware of lubrication procedures for different motors and all motors greased as per these procedures. Mud pump 4 shut down and drilling operations resumed. TOFS and MOC conducted. Mud pump isolated and swapped out with spare motor stored on the rig.

Pop off valve went on mud pump #2 while drilling @ 3100psi, unable to reset same. Valve did not see a pressure spike and was tested to 3500psi, Noted that during investigation while stripping down the relief valve it was found that the internal seal shaft had (Sub) cracked and broke off the internal sub. Currently inspecting and testing 1 x spare valves, replace old valves for new if required. Installed refurbished complete body and pop off unit. Increased pulsation damper pressure for m 800psi to 1200psi

Driller started mud pump #1, to start circulation. Pump man called to shut down mud pump. He said the low pressure pop off (PRV) on low pressure line leaking into (containment) catch pan under the pump. TOFS was called to troubleshoot pump. This is not uncommon with this low pressure PRV. In the past suction lines did not have a low pressure pop off valve. Not sure if the 14.3 ppg drilling fluid can affect this #1 Mud Pump was taken off line and Isolated. A new PRV was removed from the warehouse and installed on mud pump #1 suction line.

Drilling suspended while troubleshooting low charge pressure on hex pumps. While drilling 16-1/2" OH at 1050gpm with 14.1ppg SBM (& boosting at 350gpm = 1400gpm total) we encountered the suction charge pressure on the hex pumps slowly reducing from ~65psi down to ~15psi and triggering the pump to shut down once the charge pressure dropped below the threshold of 20-15 psi (as per design of the hex pumps). Within the last week, we had displaced the riser from 12.4ppg to SW (tropical storm), went back to mud and have weighted up to 14.1ppg. We had cleaned all the suction strainers on 10-21-19 (minimum in them) after displacing back to mud and seeing similar trends. We will continue to monitor charge pressure and take appropriate actions to minimize downtime, by precautionarily checking suction strainers when operations allow. We cleaned suction strainers (finding minimum material in same), added mud to active system to increase hydrostatic pressure on suction lines, swapped from port side active pits (normal line up) to starboard side active pits, checked for unusual barite fill in pump suction lines, checked milliamps on suction pressure transducers, tried multiple pump line ups / configurations including all pumps running at moderate speed to minimum pumps running at high speed.

Mud Pump Power Phaseback at MP Stp Setpoint Breakdown Job Equipment did not perform as intended per designed specification and not due to lack of maintenance  While conducting rounds in the drill shack we were made aware of a mud pump issue. They reported that they had a power phase back on the mud pumps that they believed was a VMS phaseback. The 3 synced mud pumps (1 2 3) were being ramped up together to a higher stroke per minute count and they reached the mud pump standpipe pressure limit setpoint of 4500psi. At this point the system phased back the power to the mud pumps due to it hitting the setpoint. Also at the same time the power phase back alarm came in another alarm came in labelled Main Synce Deactivated Due to Standpipe Pressure Limit Active. The combination of these two alarms caused the mud pumps to cycle back their strokes per minute to lower pressure below the setpoint. However the pressure setpoint they had set for pumps 1 through 3 were the same as the mud standpipe pressure setpoint. After being throttled back they pumped back up to their setpoint which was also the point that deactivates the sync and phases back the power. Note this is NOT a VMS phaseback its internal to the drilling system. At the time this happened the plant was currently at 40% utilization well under the point the mud pumps will be phased back by VMS. Currently the set point adjust for MP3 is still grayed out on the screen. We suspect this is due to the constant cycling of MP sync by the system combined with the low memory availability of the servers. We have been getting memory utilization alarms all day on the various cyberbase servers. We will keep this job open until we have had a chance to reboot the servers clear up memory on ehawk and the chairs and to compare software among all the mud pumps. I suspect that if mud pump 3 was completely shut down and brought back up it would fix the graying out of its setpoint button.----------, There have been no additional problems with this issue.

While drilling 12 1/4 hole at depth 2401m, observed fluid discharging from top of Pulsation dampener on #2 mud pump.. Bladder in dampener failed. Loss of pressure. Follow RMS procedures, regular checks while in use. Age of bladder that we replaced was 20 months. Last replaced 23rd March 2018. TOFS. Shut down pumps and isolate #2 mud pump. Circulate clean and POOH to shoe. Start replacement of bladder in pulsation dampener. Replace same.

Mud pump #2 discharge module cap seal is leaking and only one mud pump was available due to pumps 3 and 4 were being worked on. Note that the mud pump uses P-Quip valve cover retention system. The mud pump pumping rate was increased from 1000gpm to 1200gpm, and the pressure increased to 4950psi during the pump rate testing. Not long after the pump rate increased, the module cap seals started to fail. The 1200 ft-lb torque used for making up the P-Quip valve cover initially was not sufficient to hold the pressure increase. Note that during drilling the pump pressure was 3600 psi. Increased the bolt torque value to 1400 ft-lbs. Note that P-Quip gives a working range from 600-1900 ft-lbs depending on the pump pressure. Replaced the cap seal, re-torqued the P-Quip valve cover retention system bolts to 1400 ft-lbs when installing the valve cover back and re-torqued the remaining valve covers on mud pump #2.

Piston blew on #1 mud pump and #4 mud pump while drilling 12 1/4" hole section. The piston failure on #1 mud pump, #3 piston. It was taken off line and mud pump #4 was put online, only to have the same failure on #4 mud pump. Now 2 pumps are down due to failure of pistons. Mud pumps( #1 and #4) went down, leaving only #3 mud pump, which can not maintain drilling parameters. The #2 has been down graded due to pulsation dampener and can only be used on the boost to keep it low pressure. Replace #2 Mud Pump Dampener so the pump can be used on the main hole and not just the boost. Discuss with the client about a possible max hour that can be run. Then change piston considering hours only. NOT the wear. Driller continued to circulate with the bit off bottom, while #1 mud pump was isolated and repaired. Mud pump #1 was de-isolated and put back on line. #4 mud pump was isolated and fixed off line after the rig was off down time.

During Drilling Operations with three Mud Pumps the Drilling Department reported erratic indications with flow rates and pressures etc. Maintenance Department called and initial diagnosis was an imbalance with regards Load Sharing of the Mud Pumps. However, after further testing this proved to be false. Further investigation revealed an issue with Mud Pump #3 DC Drive Motor A. Drilling Department informed and Mud Pump #3 taken out of operation and isolated for further investigation. Drilling Operations continued with two Mud Pumps at reduced flow rates etc. Mud Pump #3 DC Drive Motor A - Flashover of the Commutator due to excessively worn Motor Brushes. SPM-C_MTR_ALL-DC-HOR-MOUNT-500+_90-ELECTRICAL Calendar based PM Task last completed on Mud Pump #3 Drive Motor A on 19 Sep 2018. RMS Job Task 17-1227416 refers. Approximate Mud Pump #3 Run Hours at this time - 34267Hrs. Mud Pump #3 Run Hours on 22 Dec 2018 recorded as 35176Hrs. Above Calendar based PM Task next scheduled 5 Jan 2019. In light of the above issue, RMS C/R 1700001002553 submitted to increase the frequency of this Calendar based PM Task to every 60 Days or alternatively change the PM Task to Usage Based every 750Hrs Mud Pump Run Time. As indicated above, after initial fault investigation, Drilling Operations recommenced with two Mud Pumps, Mud Pump #1 & Mud Pump #2, at a reduced flow rate. Mud Pump # 3 isolated, Drive Motor A worn Motor Brushes removed, Drive Motor cleaned internally, Commutator inspected, dressed as required, confirmed serviceable and replacement Motor Brushes installed. Drive Motor electrical readings taken and confirmed the Drive Motor as serviceable. Drive Motor B Motor Brushes checked and confirmed serviceable. Mud Pump #3 de-isolated and tested with assistance from the Drilling Department. Mud Pump confirmed fully serviceable and returned to normal Operations. Further checks on Mud Pumps #1 & #2 Drive Motors confirmed Motor Brushes on these Motors serviceable.

Blower motor (B) on mud pump #3 tripped two times @ 16:30 and 16:51 hours causing motor (B) to trip. Due to run speed and pressure of the mud pump, the loss of a motor would cause the mud pump to shut down. Electricians believe that a faulty pressure switch on the mud pump #3 blower (B) is causing the issue. Electricians to continue trouble shooting blower motor (B) on mud pump #3 to verify if the pressure switch is the culprit, or if another problem exists. Pressure switch was replaced, no further issues observed. Also, Engineering group is working with NOV to remove the loss of blower pressure as a Shutdown condition as this is historically treated as a Start Inhibit. Mud pump #3 was able to return to operation by simply turning the mud pump off, and then turning back on. On second shut down of the mud pump the lineup was changed to place Mud Pump #3 on the boost line to reduce the workload on the pump.

Check Mud Pump 3A Motor Winding RTD's Check Mud Pump 3A Motor Winding RTD's Normal expected wear and tear from operating equipment as designed  This job can be closing now as we don't get an alarms since all rtd's connections was checked.----------, This job created to follow up on issue with Mud Pump 3A motor high temperature alarms happened during operation on 16042019. Checked Mud Pump 3A Motor winding thermistors. Disconnected and checked all RTD's resistance. RTD #1: 113.5 ohms RTD #2: 113.6 ohms RTD #3: 113.1 ohms Spare RTD's reading are 113.0 113.8 ohms. Reconnected all wiring and RTD's. Checked all terminal connections for tightness. Equipment back in serive.

Washout on fluidend MP # 3, Cyl # 2, between suction valve seat and fluidend boddy. Dismounted fluidend and replaced with new.13,5 hrs downtime. Hours on Fluidend - 3770, installed 31.12.16. Hours on valves and seat - 118. The reason for replacing the module was due to washout in the seal area for the suction valve. Washout of this kind is often caused by a foreign object in the mud, damaging the valve seal. The module we replaced had only 3762 running hours. Normal lifespan for a module is around 13000 running hours, if we do not experience accidental damage such as the above. Inspect fluid ends on all MP`s. Dismounted fluidend and replaced with new.

Mud Pump 4 shut down with no audible alarms but SDI alarm screen showed liner wash and lube oil pressure faults. Barrier module -N41A in mud pump control cabinet had a bad backplane connection. Replaced module and found one of the connection stabs deformed, making intermittent contact. The module was not removed previously so it is likely the connection was damaged when the module was originally installed. No damage to backplane was observed. Researching replacement backplane part(s) to add to min/max. Pump alignment was changed to allow #2 pump to be used on the Boost line for MPD. Audible and visual alarms tested and worked as designed.

Failed valve cap seal on mud pump 4 bay 3 suction module whilst drilling 16.5" x 20" hole section under MPD conditions. Failed cap seal. Continue to inspect and verify condition at every opportunity. Fluid weep observed from tell tale indication of impending failure of valve cap seal on MP4. TOFs held. MOC process conducted. Controlled change over for mud pump line up. The MPD process means utilizing cementer to pump and allow cement pump to take over booster pump task to allow controlled reduction on drill string flow whilst maintaining back pressure on well. Reducing flow on string whilst XT reamer is in the BHA also triggers re-indexing event on the reamer as string pumps are cycled. Mud pump repaired "Offline"
